author: By Sophie Bew
title: In London, a Taiwanese Feast With Fortune-Telling Buns
description: The founders of the city’s beloved Bao restaurants hosted an intimate, artistic evening at their Forest Gate home.
content: Shing Tat Chung and Erchen Chang, the husband-and-wife duo behind London’s beloved Bao restaurants, as well as Xu Teahouse & Restaurant, met while studying at London’s Slade School of Fine Art. And when Chang briefly returned to her home country of Taiwan after graduation, Chung and his sister, Wai Ting Chung, now the couple’s business partner, who’d both grown up in Nottingham ­— went along. A food-fueled road trip ensued, with the trio taking in Taipei and Yilan in the north, and Kaohsiung, Tainan and Pingtung in the south. They ate everything from braised beef tendon to pig’s blood cake — a kind of lollipop made from steamed pork blood and sticky rice coated in peanut powder — and, somewhere along the way, the idea for the Bao brand was born. It takes inspiration from their childhoods, Shing and Wai Ting’s spent partly at their parents’ Cantonese restaurants, and from the couple’s respective artistic sensibilities. Chang studied sculpture and Chung painting, though they both veered toward performance before finishing their degrees. Perhaps that, more than anything else, explains their proclivity for making and presenting food with theatrical flair.

Three inviting neighborhoods in the area — Battery Park City, TriBeCa and the South Street Seaport — are easily reached by public transportation and offer breezy marinas, ample green space, destination restaurants and a multitude of art galleries. These days, out-of-towners are in scant evidence along the waterfront and Wall Streeters just a mere trickle, apparently in no rush to return to office buildings.

content: Hi everyone, we hope wherever you are, it’s not too hot (or, at least, that you have somewhere cool to go). Then, we go deeper on a claim made by Facebook in Tuesday’s episode and share with you a special show for your weekend listening.

content: “This is like the moment in the horror movie when you think the horror is over and the credits are about to roll. And it all starts back up again.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Love Letter: Redefining a Long-Term Hookup
description: And: a wedding on the Clubhouse app.
content: Although the allure of a casual encounter often hangs on the notion of a carefree entanglement, there are actually some rules when it comes to hooking up. Top of the list is keeping your involvement brief.

title: She Heard His Voice and Found Her Soul Mate
description: Natasha Grano and Michael Graziano met through the social media app Clubhouse. About 27,000 people attended their wedding on the audio-only platform.
content: Natasha Grano and Michael Graziano said their intimate wedding with four guests on June 5 was “elegant and powerful.” Equally special was the ceremony a day after, attended by thousands on the social media app Clubhouse, where their closest confidants gather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: G.M. issues a new recall of Chevrolet Bolts over a battery fire hazard.
description: The automaker has told owners of the 51,000 vehicles, from the 2017 to 2019 model years, to take precautions until defects are remedied.
content: General Motors is recalling nearly 51,000 Chevrolet electric cars in the United States whose battery modules have been found to be at risk of catching fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Playing With Sharks’ Review: Intrepid Journeys Undersea
description: This documentary plunges into the life of the diver and marine conservationist Valerie Taylor, but her compassion for sharks is muddied by the film’s insistence on a tense mood.
content: The chipper documentary “Playing with Sharks” celebrates the life of the diver Valerie Taylor, who dedicated her career to marine photography and conservation. The film (on Disney+) plunges into Valerie’s work with sharks, which she and her husband Ron Taylor captured in a trove of close-range undersea footage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Opening Ceremony Photos: Naomi Osaka, a Drone Globe and a Lot of Empty Seats
description: Inside the Olympic Stadium in Tokyo.
content: Japan welcomed the world to the Olympic Games on Friday night. But few people were there to witness the celebration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter and Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Strikes Taliban Targets in a Show of Force in Afghanistan
description: The airstrikes showed American willingness to back up beleaguered Afghan government forces as the Taliban advance, but the extent of that willingness remains unclear.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — U.S. military aircraft struck a number of Taliban positions this week in support of faltering Afghan government forces, in one of the first significant American reactions to the insurgents’ blistering advance across Afghanistan as U.S. troops withdraw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Trudon
title: The Case for Scheduling Everything
description: Workers want to have more control over their precious hours and avoid burnout. What if the secret is a calendar full of meetings as well as “me” time?
content: Before the pandemic emptied offices and turned dining tables into desks, getting a midday haircut or heading out for 5 p.m. therapy could involve a bit of clandestine choreography: clearing one’s schedule of meetings, finding a friend to cover, then slipping out while the boss was away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Some Florida Hospitals Have More Covid Patients Than Ever Before
description: A rapid rise in Covid-19 hospitalizations in parts of the country with lagging vaccination rates is causing alarm.
content: MIAMI — A month ago, the number of Covid-19 patients admitted at two University of Florida hospitals in Jacksonville was down to 14. Now more than 140 people are hospitalized with the coronavirus, a tenfold increase over five weeks — and the highest number of Covid-19 patients this system has seen during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Meet the Crypto Nomads
description: The big money in cryptocurrency is offshore.
content: Some of the world’s most important cryptocurrency exchanges — platforms like Binance and FTX — are not based in the United States. Yet their founders grew up in North America and trace their professional roots to Wall Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: What Inflation Risks and My Intermittent Fasting Have in Common
description: Hear me out.
content: Like many people, I put on some pounds during the pandemic. Not catastrophic — I kept working out, and I think my cardio fitness has held up. But I was doing a lot less walking than normal, and also, in retrospect, engaged in too much comfort eating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Purnell Choppin, 91, Dies; Researcher Laid Groundwork for Pandemic Fight
description: He explored how viruses multiply. An accomplished administrator, he also turned the Howard Hughes Medical Institute into a global biomedical powerhouse.
content: Purnell Choppin, whose research on how viruses multiply helped lay the foundation for today’s fight against the Covid-19 pandemic, died on July 3 at his home in Washington, one day shy of his 92nd birthday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: N.F.L. Sets Stiff Penalties for the Unvaccinated, Jolting Teams
description: Commissioner Roger Goodell said outbreaks traced to an unvaccinated player or staff member could warrant a game forfeiture for their teams. The announcement prompted a backlash from some players.
content: Throughout the off-season, the N.F.L. had stopped short of requiring that its players and other team personnel receive a Covid-19 vaccination, instead strongly encouraging inoculation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: How (and Why) the Metro Desk Photographed 115 Service Workers
description: The New Yorkers who kept the city moving were often overlooked. Portraits put their faces in the center of the frame.
content: In January, Jeffrey Furticella, photo editor for The Times’s Metro desk, read a staggering figure. The previous month, when a second wave of the coronavirus in New York prompted new restrictions on bars and restaurants, more than 11,000 service industry workers in the city were laid off. It was one last punch to the sector in a year when 200,000 hospitality jobs disappeared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: How Blue Cities Became So Outrageously Unaffordable
description: How did the party of big government become the party of paralysis?
content: Joe Biden’s economic agenda is centered on a basic premise: The United States needs to build. To build roads and bridges. To build child care facilities and car-charging stations. To build public transit and affordable housing. And in doing so, to build a better future for everyone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: How a Frontline Nurse Trained for the Olympics in a Time of Pandemic
description: When the coronavirus hit her home country, Joan Poh, Singapore’s only female rower competing in Tokyo, had to juggle a return to her hospital work with getting ready for the Games.
content: Follow our live coverage of the 2021 Tokyo Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Ellin
title: Sixty Guests at a ‘Six-Word’ Wedding
description: Lauren Few proposed to Taylor Hollenkamp last year in a six-word challenge. They were married on the six-year anniversary of the Supreme Court’s marriage equality ruling.
content: The entire world, it seemed, knew that Taylor Hollenkamp had received a marriage proposal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maia Szalavitz
title: How Drug Users Developed a Key Approach to Fighting Covid
description: Harm reduction is a gift from some of society’s most demonized people.
content: When I was using heroin in New York City in 1986, half of all the people in the city who injected drugs were H.I.V.-positive. When a friend taught me to run bleach through my syringe at least twice and then rinse twice with water before injecting, she most likely saved my life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Michael Simon Johnson, Sydney Harper, Soraya Shockley, Chris Wood and Dan Powell
title: Putting a Price on Pollution
description: The European Union has an ambitious plan to phase out the bloc’s reliance on fossil fuels. Will it work?
content: Extreme weather across Europe, North America and Asia is highlighting a harsh reality of science and history: The world as a whole is neither prepared to slow down climate change nor live with it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arthur Lubow
title: Stumbling Upon Greatness: Discovering Sergio Larrain
description: The magical images of the reclusive Chilean photographer deserve wider recognition.
content: Back in 1977, working in my first journalism job, I picked up a couple of LPs that caught my eye on the “slush pile” of publicists’ mailings, took them home, and heard with amazement the intoxicating music of the English singer-songwriter Nick Drake, who died in 1974. Obsessed, I traveled to England and wrote the first full-length magazine article on him in this country, thrilled that I could spread the good news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Isabelia Herrera, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Lil Nas X and Jack Harlow’s Prison Break, and 13 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Remi Wolf, Camila Cabello, the War on Drugs and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

title: We Need a New Term for Video Games
description: We’re seeing a ton of new games, and many of them blur the lines between video games and other types of activities.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Boyer-Dry
title: What’s the Best Way to Protect Sex Workers? Depends on Whom You Ask.
description: There are two competing bills in New York: One would punish pimps and customers, while the other would decriminalize the entire trade.
content: TS Candii first traded sex at age 13, after she was forced out of her family home in Tennessee. To survive, she decided to lie about her age, she said, taking refuge with a group of older transgender women who became her mentors. They taught her how to support herself through sex, warning that she would have few options in the formal economy, which is often intolerant of trans people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: Greg Knapp, a Jets Assistant Coach, Dies at 58
description: Knapp, the team’s new passing-game specialist, was hit by a car while biking over the weekend and never regained consciousness, his family said.
content: Greg Knapp, the Jets’ passing-game specialist, died on Thursday from injuries he sustained while being struck by a car as he rode a bicycle in California last weekend. He was 58.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: She Said Yes. Twice.
description: Damon Holick asked Erica Willard, his high school sweetheart, to marry him two times. One of the proposals was captured in a photo that went viral.
content: Damon Holick could hardly believe it when his mother called in April of 2021 to say she thought she saw a photo of him on television proposing to Erica Willard. She was right. The photo of Mr. Holick on one knee in front of Ms. Willard at the pier in the Woodlands, Texas, at Hughes Landing was sent to a TV station in Houston by a woman who just happened to see the proposal in action. The sweet capture quickly went viral.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: ‘A gift from God’: Greece enlists the church in its vaccine drive.
description: The government has turned to the leaders of the powerful Orthodox Church to appeal to the faithful and rein in clerics who have been vocal about mistrusting vaccines.
content: The message from Greek officials is the same as it is from governments around the world: get vaccinated, get vaccinated, get vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Wagner
title: Songs to Accompany a Dreamy Summer Dinner Party
description: John Cale, Sharon Van Etten, Donavon Smallwood and other creative types make suggestions for an eclectic playlist sure to help set a festive mood.
content: When creating a playlist for a dinner party, it can be useful to think ahead and imagine the end of the night — should things conclude with whiskey and delayed goodbyes on the couch or with dancing into the wee hours? Because music, after all, can not only set the tone but also help determine the entire trajectory of an evening. Where to begin, though? Curating the perfect lineup can feel like a daunting task, and even music obsessives can fall into ruts and benefit from others offering up song suggestions. Recently, we asked a range of artists, musicians and other creative types to do just that, and to share a few tips on putting your selections together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: The Olympics Are Great for Streaming. But Is Streaming Great for NBC?
description: Streaming on multiple platforms lets broadcasters show more competitions than ever. But for now, the big money in sports is in ad revenue, not streaming.
content: The Olympics almost seem like they were designed for the streaming era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The True Value of Gold
description: The Olympics may be a major championship for women’s teams, but they remain an afterthought for the men.
content: Daniel Alves has seen it all, done it all. He has won league titles in three countries, picked up nine cups, conquered Europe with his club and South America with his country. He has 41 major honors to his name, officially making him the most decorated player in history. But still, when André Jardine asked him to take on one last job, his eyes lit up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: How to Make Fast, Easy Skewers on the Grill
description: Grilling season is in full swing. What better time to perfect this often-tricky technique?
content: It’s one of the most elemental cooking techniques: impaling food on a skewer or a stick and cooking it over an open fire.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen warned Congress on Friday that the U.S. economy faced “irreparable harm” if lawmakers failed to raise or suspend the nation’s borrowing cap and that the Treasury Department would begin taking “extraordinary measures” to avoid breaching the so-called debt limit.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Prices are rising rapidly, and elevated inflation is likely to remain through at least the next year. Congress shouldn’t make matters worse by signing a $4 trillion check for President Biden’s economic plan, which Democratic leaders are looking to push through even without Republican support.

title: Buy My House, But I’m Taking the Toilet
description: In this seller’s market, some sellers are exercising their power with unusual demands and stripping their homes of fixtures and appliances as they leave.
content: In a housing market desperately short on inventory, with prices spiraling toward the heavens, sellers can demand almost anything these days. They can even take the toilets.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Men Who Beat Hong Kong Protesters in Mob Attack Are Sentenced to Prison
description: In his ruling, a judge in Hong Kong said that the seven defendants had “viciously” attacked innocent people in a train station in July 2019.
content: HONG KONG — A Hong Kong judge has sentenced seven men to prison for their roles in a 2019 mob attack on unarmed people in a subway station, which shocked the city and injured dozens, including pro-democracy protesters.

title: Arturo Schwarz, Refugee Who Became a Surrealism Tycoon, Dies at 97
description: After expulsion from Egypt left him penniless, he befriended André Breton and Marcel Duchamp and amassed an enormous collection of priceless art.
content: Growing up in the 1930s and ’40s in the cosmopolitan port city of Alexandria, Egypt, Arturo Schwarz idolized European intellectuals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Museler
title: Bruce Kirby, Who Transformed Sailing With a ‘Doodle,’ Dies at 92
description: On yellow legal paper, Mr. Kirby, a self-taught designer and Olympic sailor, came up with an impromptu design for a lightweight craft that changed the face of sailing.
content: Bruce Kirby, a Canadian-born journalist, Olympic sailor and self-taught naval architect whose design for a lightweight fiberglass dinghy, originally sketched on a piece of yellow legal paper, changed the face of sailing, died on Monday at his home in the village of Rowayton in Norwalk, Conn. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Olympic protesters made themselves heard during the opening ceremony.
description: Their chants and whistles could easily be heard inside the nearly empty stadium.
content: Follow our live coverage of the Tokyo Olympics.

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Vladimir Menshov, Surprise Russian Oscar Winner, Dies at 81
description: His “Moscow Does Not Believe in Tears” was named best foreign-language film in 1980, beating Truffaut and Kurosawa. U.S. critics demurred.
content: Vladimir Menshov, a prolific Soviet actor and director whose film “Moscow Does Not Believe in Tears” won the Academy Award in 1980 for best foreign-language film, surprising the many American critics who had panned it, died on July 5 in a hospital in Moscow. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Testing Britney Spears: Restoring Rights Can Be Rare and Difficult
description: To get out of conservatorship, the pop star will likely have to undergo a psychiatric evaluation, an uneasy melding of legal standards and mental health criteria.
content: Her voice quaking with anger and despair, the pop star Britney Spears has asked repeatedly in court to be freed from the conservatorship that has controlled her money and personal life for 13 years. What’s more, she asked the judge to sever the arrangement without making her undergo a psychological evaluation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bethany Mandel
title: Forget Mask Mandates. Vaccines Are the Only Answer for Fighting Covid-19.
description: I’m done with masks and lockdowns.
content: It’s not often that I say this as a conservative, but Mayor Bill de Blasio is absolutely correct to reject calls for a renewed indoor mask mandate and to refuse to consider renewed lockdowns in New York City in light of the emergence of the Delta variant. “A mask doesn’t arrest the progress of the variant,” Mr. de Blasio said, explaining how following the science led him to be reluctant to reinstitute the mandate this week. “Vaccination does.” This holds true not just for New York City: reinstituting mask mandates and lockdowns would be a mistake nationwide as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Thomas Barrack, Trump’s friend and fund-raiser, is freed on $250 million bond.
description: The agreement requires Mr. Barrack to wear a GPS location monitoring bracelet at all times.
content: WASHINGTON — Thomas J. Barrack Jr., a longtime Trump fund-raiser and friend, has reached an agreement with federal prosecutors to be released on $250 million bond while awaiting trial on charges that he illegally lobbied the U.S. government on behalf of leaders in the United Arab Emirates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: Bulgogi, Any Way You Slice It
description: From its origins in ancient Korea to kitchens across the diaspora today, this staple of Korean barbecue means something different to everyone.
content: In a spiral-bound police community cookbook from the 1970s, Songza Park’s recipe for “BUL KOGI (Barbecued Beef)” calls for two pounds of sirloin steak that you have to slice “very thin on the bias” before scoring each piece with an X. In 1965, when Ms. Park immigrated to the United States from Korea, she had no access to Korean grocery stores, where today entire cases are dedicated to pre-sliced meat often labeled “bulgogi beef.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: New in Paperback: ‘Transcendent Kingdom’ and ‘Agent Sonya’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: TRANSCENDENT KINGDOM, by Yaa Gyasi. (Vintage, 304 pp., $16.) Gyasi’s second novel trades the “blazing brilliance” of her first, “Homegoing,” for a “more granular” type of glory, Nell Freudenberger wrote in her review. The transcendent kingdom of the title is the “primal connection” a Ghanaian American neuroscience graduate student and her depressive, religious, immigrant mother maintain as they weather the racism that follows them everywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: One by One, African Countries Dismantle Colonial-Era Death Penalty Laws
description: In a unanimous vote by lawmakers, Sierra Leone became the 23rd African country to abolish capital punishment. Critics called it an inhumane vestige of colonialism.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — Lawmakers in Sierra Leone voted unanimously on Friday to abolish the death penalty, a momentous step that made the West African country the 23rd on the continent to prohibit capital punishment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘Woodstock 99: Peace, Love and Rage’ Review: How a Festival Went Wrong
description: An HBO documentary examines a music festival that went so far off the rails that it defined an era.
content: It is mildly surprising that it took so long for a documentary about the 1999 edition of the Woodstock music festival to be made. After all, this was an epic, epoch-defining debacle that deserves more scrutiny than, say, the Fyre Festival, a preposterous fiasco from 2017 that crashed before actually happening yet has already prompted two films about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: How to Survive a Plague, Part 2
description: The resistance to Covid vaccinations is eerily familiar to those who lived through the early days of the AIDS crisis.
content: This week, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced that workers in the city hospital system would be required to get the Covid vaccine or submit to weekly testing. If you were surprised by the development, it was almost certainly because you assumed that nurses and doctors and orderlies and administrators — those with such an intimate connection to so much devastation — had been vaccinated already for months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Firshein
title: Help! I’m Traveling to Europe. All the Requirements Are a Dizzying Mess.
description: For three confused but vaccinated travelers, our columnist tries to make sense of the new rules of entry into the European Union.
content: I know that vaccinated Americans are not required to quarantine when visiting France, but are they required to take a Covid test — either going there or returning home? And although I updated my Clear app to show that I have been vaccinated, I don’t know who is responsible for looking at it: Is it the airline when you check in, an officer when you go through security or someone on the ground when you land? Bob
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart, Kyle Buchanan, Elyssa Dudley, Tracy Mumford, Theo Balcomb and Elisheba Ittoop
title: The Return of the Cannes Film Festival
description: Remember going to the movies? Here’s what it was like inside the world’s most glamorous celebration of cinema.
content: For two weeks in the south of France, you can enter the high holy temple of cinema: the Cannes Film Festival. This is the place where red carpet moments are made, where tuxedos are mandatory and where the audience will stand and clap for a full nine minutes. The celluloid soiree returned this July after last year’s cancellation because of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaya Laterman
title: What Happens When Your Waiter Can’t Afford Rent
description: Many towns in rural New York are bustling with city visitors, pushing up rental costs and pushing out workers.
content: If LaToya Flood had her way, she would hire an additional five to seven employees at Ruby Mae Soul Food Restaurant, which she has operated for three years in Kingston, N.Y. With her business open now just on Fridays and Saturdays, Ms. Flood and her sole employee, her mother, prepare all week for what could be a thriving, full-time business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jewel Wicker
title: Kanye West Unveils ‘Donda’ Album, With a Verse From Jay-Z
description: As fans packed the Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta to get a first listen, West danced in a spotlight but chose not to say a word.
content: ATLANTA — A man who is rarely short on words, Kanye West didn’t even have a microphone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelly Whiteside
title: Three-on-Three Basketball at the Olympics: What to Watch For
description: The United States is favored to win a gold medal behind a roster of young W.N.B.A. standouts.
content: Eighty-five years after basketball’s debut in the Olympics, at the 1936 Berlin Games, a twist on the sport makes its Olympic debut in Tokyo. Three-on-three basketball, or 3x3 as the sport’s world governing body refers to it, promises a faster version than the traditional form.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Federal efforts to stave off an eviction crisis gain some momentum.
description: The amount of money sent to tenants in June was greater than the disbursements of the previous two months combined, according to the Treasury Department.
content: The Biden administration’s effort to head off a crisis when the federal moratorium on evictions expires at the end of the month is gaining modest momentum, with 290,000 tenants receiving $1.5 billion in pandemic relief in June, according to new Treasury Department statistics.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jill Biden cheers for the American athletes in Tokyo.
description: The first lady traveled to Japan as the leader of a small presidential delegation, and her appearance came amid concerns of skyrocketing coronavirus cases in country.
content: Follow our live coverage of the Tokyo Olympics.

description: Dip into these picture books about pools and beaches, swimming and sailing, calm waters and stormy seas.
content: CHOICESWritten and illustrated by Roozeboos

author: By Brian Seibert
title: A Vogue Legend, Still Enlarging Circles of Pleasure
description: Archie Burnett, dancer, teacher and a grandfather of the House of Ninja, has a show at Jacob’s Pillow. With his cast, “it’s like a family love affair.”
content: When Archie Burnett walks onto a dance floor, he tends to take it over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: They Live in an N.Y.C. Virus Hot Spot. But They Won’t Get Vaccinated.
description: Staten Island’s recent uptick in coronavirus cases foretold a larger increase across New York City.
content: On Staten Island’s South Shore, the sole mass vaccination site — an elementary school’s gymnasium — closed down this week, and was replaced by a vaccination van that has been giving fewer than 10 shots a day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: As July Nears Its End, Teams Must Decide What They Are
description: The always-confounding Tampa Bay Rays have already been buyers and sellers in a lead-up to the trade deadline, which may see big changes for the Chicago Cubs and others.
content: In baseball, the lineups of late July can look like relics within a week. Six years ago on Friday, the Mets used left fielder John Mayberry Jr. as their cleanup hitter against Clayton Kershaw of the Los Angeles Dodgers. Eight days later, Yoenis Cespedes was on his way to New York; the Mets were on their way to the World Series; and Mayberry’s career in the majors was over.

title: How Tech Won the Pandemic and Now May Never Lose

content: SAN FRANCISCO — In April 2020, with 2,000 Americans dying every day of Covid-19, Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive and the world’s richest man, announced he was focusing on people rather than profits. Amazon would spend about $4 billion in the next few months “providing for customers and protecting employees,” he said, wiping out the profit the retailer would have made without the virus.

content: Science Fiction was extraordinarily popular in the 1940s and 1950s — and so were books about U.F.O.s. Coverage of mysterious objects in the night sky was plentiful in The Times, too. On July 6, 1947, the front page featured an article headlined “Flying Saucers Mystify Experts; May Be Prank of Nature.” Two days later, a follow-up appeared, also on the front page, with a more provocative headline: “‘Disks’ Soar Over New York, Now Seen Aloft in All Colors.” It should perhaps come as no surprise that those years saw the Book Review filled with ads looking to sate this interest in the extraterrestrial and dystopian.

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Try Gabrielle Hamilton’s sous-chef salad, a take on a classic French salade composée.
content: Good morning. “I don’t question that the greatest meal salad of all time, the chef salad, was created by a chef,” Gabrielle Hamilton wrote for The New York Times Magazine this week. “The combination of textures and flavors is consummately professional. Sometimes people mistake the salad bowl for a lawless place of disorganized and mismatched ingredients, chopped up and thrown in — dried cranberries on top of pumpkin seeds on top of soggy corn — which offends even me, who stakes no strong claim to her chef bona fides. A salad nonetheless requires a bit of cheffing, a little experienced attention paid to balance, texture and restraint. Not everything tastes better with bacon bits scattered on top.”

title: Corrections: July 23, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, July 23, 2021.
content: An article on Thursday about Martine Moïse’s return to Haiti after being wounded in the attack that killed her husband, President Jovenel Moïse, misstated Ms. Moïse’s remarks about her husband’s funeral. As the article correctly pointed out elsewhere, she said that her family would pay for the funeral and that public funds would not be sought. She did not say that public money would be used.
